source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: Under severe fuel-damage (SFD) conditions a combined external and internal oxidation of the fuel-rod cladding occurs due to a reaction with steam or oxygen on the outside surface and the UO2 fuel on the inside surface.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The reaction kinetics have been studied with isothermal and transient temperature experiments above 500°C

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The tests were performed using short LWR fuel-rod sections in an (Ar + 25 vol% O2) environment.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The present work describes the results of out-of-pile annealing experiments with LWR fuel-rod sections conducted from 900 to 2000°C in an oxidizing atmosphere under isothermal and transient temperature conditions.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The present work describes the results of out-of-pile annealing experiments with LWR fuel-rod sections conducted from 900 to 2000°C in an oxidizing atmosphere under isothermal and transient temperature conditions.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The out-of-pile UO2/Zry reaction experiments were performed in an (Ar + 25 vol% O2) gas mixture

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The tests were made using short cladding tube specimens filled with stoichiometric high-density UO2 pellets.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The specimens were 100 mm long with an outside diameter of 10.75 mm and a wall thickness of 0.72 mm.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The specimens were 100 mm long with an outside diameter of 10.75 mm and a wall thickness of 0.72 mm.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The specimens were 100 mm long with an outside diameter of 10.75 mm and a wall thickness of 0.72 mm.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The maximum cladding temperature was 2000°C, and the annealing times varied between 1 and 150 min.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The maximum cladding temperature was 2000°C, and the annealing times varied between 1 and 150 min.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The external overpressure was about 40 bar in most of the experiments.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: Due to oxygen uptake by the Zry cladding from reaction with gaseous oxygen on the outside and from reaction with UO2 on the inside, oxygen-stabilized α-Zr(O) phases, ZrO2, and a metallic (U,Zr) alloy form.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: the tubing has to be considered as a finite system. For this reason, the external and internal oxygen uptake influence each other and an accelerated reaction-layer growth is observed at longer reaction times

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: After the disappearance of the β-phase, the oxidized cladding tube is completely embrittled, and no longer mechanically stable

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: The time to embrittlement is only about 3 min for double-sided oxidation of the cladding at 1400°C

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk3
evidence_span: the cladding will be completely oxidized, depending on the heat-up and cool-down rate, between 1800 and 2000°C

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk3
evidence_span: The formation of ZrO₂ results in a diameter increase of the fuel-rod segments, since the ZrO₂ has a lower density than the Zircaloy cladding.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk3
evidence_span: No oxide spalling could be noticed.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk3
evidence_span: Specimen 177 M, Temperature: 900°C (Measured), Time: 10 min, Reaction Zone V: x=760 μm

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk3
evidence_span: Specimen 178 M, Time: 30 min, Reaction Zone IV: x=26 μm, σ=2.4 μm; Reaction Zone V: x=759 μm

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk3
evidence_span: Specimen 179 M, Time: 60 min, Reaction Zone I: x=5 μm, σ=0 μm; Reaction Zone IV: x=57 μm, σ=2.3 μm; Reaction Zone V: x=766 μm

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk7
evidence_span: Calculations with the PECLOX model were also performed for temperature transient experiments at a heat-up and cool-down rate of $1 ~ \mathrm { K } / \mathsf s$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk7
evidence_span: The maximum temperatures were 1300 and $1 5 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk7
evidence_span: The maximum temperatures were 1300 and $1 5 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk7
evidence_span: the time at maximum temperature for the calculations was in all cases ${ 1 0 \ s }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk7
evidence_span: The initial temperature was assumed to be $1 0 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk7
evidence_span: Oxygen concentration distribution in the various interaction layers at $1 1 0 0 ^ { \circ } C$ for the initial condition

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: Further model improvements are planned with respect to steam-starvation and hydrogen-blanketing conditions on the external cladding tube surface.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: The external steam/Zircaloy or oxygen/Zircaloy and internal UO2/Zircaloy chemical interactions in LWR fuel rods under SFD conditions result in the formation of following reaction layers at all temperatures examined

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: TEMPERATURE (C): 1500.0 TIME (SECONDS) : 510.0

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: Oxygen-concentration distribution in the various interaction layers during a temperature transient after 510 s (1500°C)

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: Oxygen-concentration distribution in the various interaction layers during a temperature transient after 1010 s (1000°C)

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: The growth of the reaction layer initially obeys a parabolic rate law and the diffusion of oxygen into the cladding is the rate-determining step.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: After some time, the growth rates of the various phases increase due to the finite cladding wall thickness.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: The UO2/Zircaloy reaction occurs as rapidly as the steam/Zircaloy and (Ar+25vol% O2)/Zircaloy reaction.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: The (Ar+25vol% O2) gas mixture can be used to simulate the steam environment.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: Oxygen uptake by the Zircaloy causes the cladding to become embrittled.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: Due to the combined external and internal cladding oxidation, the embrittlement of Zircaloy tubing occurs about four times faster than oxidation from either surface alone.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: Since the oxygen potential (partial pressure) of the steam or the (Ar+25vol% O2) gas mixture is higher than that of the UO2 the final stable reaction product is ZrO2.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: The initially metallic Γ(U,Zr) alloy is converted into a (U,Zr)O2 mixed-oxide phase.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk9
evidence_span: In our case isothermal oxidation experiments above 1400°C could not be performed. During the intended heatup to 1500°C an uncontrolled temperature escalation of the specimen occurred at about 1470°C due to the exothermic Zry/oxygen interaction.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk9
evidence_span: However, in a quasi-adiabatic system, such as a reactor core, temperature escalation may start sooner, between 1000 and 1100°C, as observed in tube furnace oxidation experiments.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk9
evidence_span: The influence of the initial material condition on the deformation behavior of Zircaloy cladding tubes at 600 and 800°C is systematically investigated by closed end creep rupture tests and transient burst tests in air.
test_type: creep rupture test, transient burst test

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_040_chunk9
evidence_span: At 800°C the strain rate of the cladding tube diameter can be described by the Norton creep equation
